cwe_description: The product copies an input buffer to a stack-based buffer without properly checking the size of the input buffer, which can lead to a buffer overflow. This can allow an attacker to overwrite adjacent stack memory, potentially leading to control flow hijacking or denial of service.
explanation: The code is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow. Several fixed-size arrays (arridx, curi, tword, wordcount) are allocated on the stack using the MAXWLEN constant. The 'depth' variable, which is used as an index into these arrays, is incremented without any bounds checking against MAXWLEN. If the input trie structure (derived from slang) has a depth greater than or equal to MAXWLEN, the 'depth' variable will exceed the allocated array bounds, leading to out-of-bounds writes when accessing elements like arridx[depth], curi[depth], tword[depth], or wordcount[depth]. This can result in denial of service, data corruption, or potentially arbitrary code execution.

cwe_description: The product writes data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can corrupt data, crash the program, or lead to the execution of arbitrary code.
explanation: The code uses fixed-size arrays (arridx, curi, tword, wordcount) of size MAXWLEN. The 'depth' variable is used as an index into these arrays and is incremented without bounds checking against MAXWLEN. If the input trie structure (derived from slang->sl_fbyts and slang->sl_fidxs) has a depth greater than or equal to MAXWLEN, an out-of-bounds write will occur when accessing these arrays, specifically at lines like tword[depth++] = c; and subsequent assignments using 'depth'. This can lead to memory corruption, denial of service, or potentially arbitrary code execution.
